_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



This document comprises the Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP Plan) and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP) for the Coastal Pacific Food Distributors (CPFD) facility located at 1015 Performance Drive in Stockton, California 95206 (hereinafter referred to as the facility).  This document comprises the Executive Summary for the Facility's Five Year Update of each of these two Programs.



The purpose of this document is to comply with the risk management planning requirements as set forth in the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68 (also known as the Federal Risk Management Plan Regulations) and the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Article 3, Section 2745.3 (also known as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan - CalARP RMP Regulations).  The scope of the Federal RMP and CalARP RMP includes all operations conducted at CPFD's Stockton Facility that involve the storage, handling and/or use of anhydrous ammonia (i.e., anhydrous ammonia is the only regulated substance handled at the facility above the threshold quantity).  This document contains the necessary information to satisfy the EPA Risk Management Program and the CalARP Program regulations for facilities handling regulated substances in excess of the listed threshold quantity.  Specifically, this document consists of the Executive Summary as required by 40 CFR Part 68.155 (19 CCR ?2745.3) and the Data Elements/RMPeSubmit forms as required by 40 CFR Part 68.160 - 180 (19 CCR ?2745.4 - .8).  Finally, this document contains the certification page required by 40 CFR Part 68.185 (19 CCR ?2745.9).



CPFD is strongly committed to the health and safety of its employees, the public and the environment.  This commitment is demonstrated by the comprehensive accidental release prevention program implemented at the Stockton Facility covering aspects of operations such as

design, installation, operations and maintenance, training, emergency response and other areas.  It is the Policy of CPFD to implement appropriate controls to prevent potential releases of regulated substances.  This is achieved through strong leadership, teamwork, effective communications, and by striving towards continuous improvement in all business areas.



ES 1.0    DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Facility Location

The CPFD Facility is located at 1015 Performance Drive in Stockton, California 95206 between Sperry Road and Aviation Drive.  The facility lies approximately 1.4-miles east of Interstate 5 in an area comprised primarily of agricultural and industrial facilities. The small town of French Camp is located about 1 mile southwest of the facility. The Stockton Metropolitan Airport lies approximately a ? mile east of the plant. State Highway 99 runs east-west and the closest point to the plant is about 2.5-miles to the east.  The facility also lies very close to the Union Pacific railroad tracks.  



Facility Description

CPFD's Stockton facility stores and distributes various food and non-food related supplies and encompasses approximately 500,000-square feet of space.  A portion of the Stockton Warehouse and Distribution Center space is refrigerated and cold storage.  



Description of Facility's Use of Regulated Substance



The facility utilizes an anhydrous ammonia based, single stage mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes a flooded liquid evaporator feed.  The refrigeration system contains approximately 12,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia (the only regulated substance handled at the SUPO Plant) in a closed loop process.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, and cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) to provide space refrigeration / cooling.  The re

ease scenario).



A number of hypothetical accidental release scenarios were postulated and evaluated for the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP.  These scenarios were categorized into worst-case release scenarios and alternative release scenarios.  Each of these categories of hypothetical accidental release scenarios is discussed below.



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



Worst-Case Release Scenario

In this accidental release scenario, the anhydrous ammonia high pressure receiver (HPR) on site experiences a catastrophic failure due to an unknown event.  This scenario could be initiated by an external event (i.e., an airplane, missile or meteorite impacting the area where the HPR is located).  It is highly improbable that this scenario would be initiated by a seismic event.  However, the possibility of this scenario being initiated by a seismic event cannot be completely discarded.  This scenario is considered to be extremely unlikely.  In the extremely unlikely case that this scenario occurs, up to 12,000-pounds of anhydrous ammonia could be released (in the worst-case).  



Since the release would occur inside the Refrigeration Machinery Room, the effects of Building Attenuation were considered in determining the projected vulnerable zone. Utilizing the methodology specified by USEPA, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 1.8-miles.



Alternative-Release Scenarios

Alternative accidental release scenarios which are considered to be more likely to occur (than the worst-case release scenario) are those which may result in the release of anywhere from less than one-pound to up to 1,000-pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  These scenarios include situations such as accidental releases during anhydrous ammonia delivery to- or loading of- the high pressure receiver at the facility, pinhole leaks in either the high pressure or low pressure anhydrous ammonia transfer piping (which contain anhydrous ammonia in either liquid or vapor phase),

a partial or complete failure of the anhydrous ammonia transfer lines (containing anhydrous ammonia in either liquid or vapor phase) at various points in the system (indoors or outdoors), or releases of anhydrous ammonia vapor during pressure relief events at any of a number of vessels or lines.  In order to be conservative in the estimation of the vulnerable zone, it was assumed that approximately 1,000-pounds of anhydrous ammonia (in liquid phase) is released due to a 0.25-inch pinhole leak in an ammonia liquid transfer line over a 60-minute time period.  The resulting release of ammonia vapor was assumed to freely migrate off-site.  Utilizing the USEPA's Reference Tables, the distance to endpoint for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 0.8-miles.



ES 3.0    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



In the five years preceding submittal of the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP, the facility has NOT had any releases of anhydrous ammonia that have resulted in:

?    Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.



ES 4.0    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Accidental Release Prevention Program at the CPFD Facility consists of a series of programs, procedures and policies designed to minimize the possibility of- and risk of- accidental releases involving anhydrous ammonia.  These programs include design and operating controls such as compliance with specified codes, the Company's health and safety program, numerous standard operating procedures, the equipment inspection and maintenance program (including a mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program), the management of change program, pre-start-up review, fire protection and hot work permit programs, management of- and safety of- contractors, accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plans, the Federal RMP/CalARP R

MP/OSHA PSM Program compliance auditing program, the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP/OSHA PSM Program record keeping program and a variety of personnel training programs.  Details of each of these components of the Facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program are provided in the document entitled Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP), California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM) Program, Volume I - Prevention Program.  



There are a number of detection and monitoring devices and alarms designed to ensure the continued safe operation of the Refrigeration Process (i.e., which encompasses the storage, handling and use of anhydrous ammonia).  These devices are located throughout the facility and monitor various aspects of the refrigeration system.  



ES 5.0    EMERGENCY RESPONSE



CPFD recognizes that emergency preparedness, emergency planning and emergency response are an integral component of risk management.   As such, an extensive and detailed emergency action plan has been developed and implemented for the Stockton Facility.  This Plan includes ALL aspects of emergency response including evacuation and notification of LERC/LEPD.



ALL detection, monitoring, control, and alarm devices are frequently tested, inspected and serviced to ensure proper functioning.  In addition, the emergency action plan is reviewed periodically and updated (as needed) to reflect pertinent changes in processes, operations and/or personnel that may require a modified emergency response.  Emergency evacuation drills and exercises are conducted periodically to orderly and complete evacuation.  ALL employees and contractors are trained in the requirements of these emergency action plan.



ES 6.0    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



A detailed hazard and operability study (i.e., process hazards analysis) was performed (prior to system startup) on ALL operations involving anhydrous ammonia in order to enhance t

he safety of the CPFD Facility and to evaluate the potential for accidental releases and minimize those releases to the maximum extent practicable.  As a result of the process hazards analysis performed a number of recommendations to improve safety were made.  All recommendations made were implemented.  The PHA was updated in 2015 and all recommendations were implemented.  Another Five Year PHA Update is scheduled for November 2019.



ES 7.0    FOR MORE INFORMATION



CPFD recognizes that some persons may be interested in obtaining more detailed information regarding the Federal RMP and CalARP RMP or the various Prevention Program components not discussed in detail herein.  Interested parties that have additional questions regarding the Stockton Facility and/or the Anhydrous Ammonia Release Prevention Program, are directed to contact:



    Mr. James Rutta

    Operations Manager

    c/o Coastal Pacific Food Distributors

    1015 Performance Drive

    Stockton, California 95206
